title: Simple Present Tense
content_text: The simple present tense is used to describe habits, facts, and general truths. For example: "I drink coffee every morning" or "The sun rises in the east."
explanation: Use simple present for routines and facts.

title: Basic Greetings
content_text: Common greetings in English include: "Hello", "Hi", "Good morning", "Good afternoon", "Good evening", and "Goodbye". Use "Hello" or "Hi" for informal situations.
explanation: Greetings are the first words you learn in any language.

title: Present Continuous Tense
content_text: The present continuous tense is used to describe actions happening now or temporary situations. Form: subject + am/is/are + verb-ing. Example: "I am studying English right now."
explanation: Use present continuous for actions happening at the moment.

title: Countable and Uncountable Nouns
content_text: Countable nouns can be counted (one apple, two apples). Uncountable nouns cannot be counted (water, rice, information). Use "a/an" with countable nouns and "some/any" with uncountable nouns.
explanation: Understanding countable vs uncountable helps with correct article usage.

title: Past Perfect Tense
content_text: The past perfect tense is used to show that one action happened before another in the past. Form: had + past participle. Example: "I had finished my homework before I went to bed."
explanation: Past perfect shows the earlier of two past actions.

title: First Conditional
content_text: The first conditional is used for real future possibilities. Structure: If + present simple, will + infinitive. Example: "If it rains tomorrow, I will stay home."
explanation: First conditional expresses likely future outcomes.

title: Passive Voice
content_text: The passive voice is used when the action is more important than who does it. Form: be + past participle. Example: "The book was written by a famous author." vs "A famous author wrote the book."
explanation: Passive voice shifts focus from the doer to the action.

title: Reported Speech
content_text: Reported speech (indirect speech) changes the tense when reporting what someone said. "I am tired" becomes "He said he was tired." Present becomes past, past becomes past perfect.

title: Third Conditional
content_text: The third conditional expresses hypothetical past situations. Structure: If + past perfect, would have + past participle. Example: "If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam."
explanation: Third conditional describes impossible past scenarios.

title: Mixed Conditionals
content_text: Mixed conditionals combine different time frames. Example: "If I had learned English earlier (past), I would be fluent now (present)." This combines past perfect with present conditional.
explanation: Mixed conditionals connect past actions to present results.

title: Subjunctive Mood
content_text: The subjunctive mood expresses wishes, suggestions, or hypothetical situations. Example: "I wish I were taller" (not "was"). "It's important that he be on time" (not "is").
explanation: Subjunctive mood is used for hypothetical or formal expressions.

title: Inversion for Emphasis
content_text: Inversion is used for emphasis in formal English. Instead of "Never have I seen such beauty," we invert: "Never have I seen such beauty." Common with negative adverbs: never, rarely, seldom, hardly.
explanation: Inversion adds emphasis and formality to statements.
